SEG.ORIGINAL_TEXT: Government Human Error Allowed Dylann Roof To Buy His Murder Weapon
Dylann Roof walked into a gun store on April 11, 2015, and began the legal process to purchase a weapon...

...the meat of that process is a full background check of the buyer by the FBI's National Instant Criminal Background Check System (NICS). By law, once the background check is submitted by the gun store owner, the FBI has 3 business days to approve it, or deny it with cause. By law, if the FBI doesn't respond back to gun store owner within that legal 3 day period, the gun store owner is then free to complete the purchase and deliver the gun to the buyer.

Many background checks are completed quickly: when a buyer has a clean record, and depending on the time of day, one can be approved almost immediately and the buyer leaves the store with his new weapon...

...immediately upon receiving and processing Roof's background, the FBI learned Roof had been arrested less than two months earlier on February 28, 2015 for misdemeanor drug possession charges; they also saw he had been arrested again at the same shopping mall where his February arrest had occurred, this time for trespassing. Neither arrest legally allows the FBI to automatically deny a weapon purchase, so Roof's background check was yellow-flagged for further investigation - the resolutions of his arrests had to be discovered.
So far, the background check process was working exactly as advertised.
...because 2 full days passed before an examiner started further investigating into Roof's drug charges with only that 1 remaining day to wrap it up.

Unfortunately, with all the FBI investigative tools available to the examiner for just that job, the examiner could never figure-out which police department had arrested Roof, so the examiner failed to obtain the police report on Roof's misdemeanor drug possession arrest..

...if the examiner would have just found that report, the examiner would've read that Roof confessed to prior drug use when he was arrested - which is automatic cause to deny a weapon purchase. Discovering that, the examiner would've instantly denied Roof's purchase.
Not being able to find the police report, the examiner sent a request for more info to the county prosecutor office which charged Roof.
But, the prosecutor's office didn't respond to her request and the examiner evidently didn't consider it vital enough to keep her nose to the case she'd been assigned...
...so the next day, the legal 3-day waiting period now expired, Dylann Roof took possession of the .45 caliber handgun he would cold-bloodedly murder 9 human beings with two months later on June 17.
I hold no one else responsible for those 9 murdered human lives except the murderer...
...the person fully responsible regardless of any other factors.
I also believe that if Roof would've been rightly denied purchasing a weapon on April 11...
...he very well might've obtained a weapon some other way.

...the FBI most certainly failed the very law which was specifically enacted and in place to prevent Roof's weapon purchase from completing. And I truly believe that failure can be squarely placed on whatever delayed the investigation to begin for 2 days (bureaucracy?), and then responsibility must be assigned to the examiner who failed her job.
What I'd like to know is when the FBI discovered this failure: was Roof's background check still pending on the night of the murders?

Because if it was, that points to even more intolerable lack of action: if the FBI would've found out Roof could not legally buy a weapon even a week, or a month, or a month and a half after he'd already bought it, the FBI at least could've visited Roof and confiscated the weapon.
It reads to me like Roof's background check was still sitting around the FBI - unresolved - when Roof walked into Emanuel AME and made Satan proud.
That's a horrifically big-time fuck up.

Not really. Delays can happen, that's the nature of things. Human error this time. Random mishap next time. Illness, backlog and understaffing, system crash, lighning strike, what-have-you.

The big time fuck up is whoever penned a law so moronic that it doesn't take into account that shit happens, and esentially... no, strike that... literally allowed the sale of the gun without a completed background check.

A non idiotic law would of course reprimand those responsible for non force majeure delays, but wouldn't automatically toss the idea behind background checks out the window just because something went wrong.
